body: Support DragonFlyBSD, use sed(1) instead of rev(1) and cut(1), use variables via env(1) too. --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/toxic/23)

comment_regular_data.body:
[![CLA assistant check](https://cla-assistant.io/pull/badge/not_signed)](https://cla-assistant.io/TokTok/toxic?pullRequest=23)
Thank you for your submission, we really appreciate it. Like many open source projects, we ask that you sign our [Contributor License Agreement](https://cla-assistant.io/TokTok/toxic?pullRequest=23) before we can accept your contribution.
You have signed the CLA already but the status is still pending? Let us [recheck](https://cla-assistant.io/check/TokTok/toxic?pullRequest=23) it.
Thanks. What does AIO mean?
@iphydf All In One :)
Ok, can you give this a better title that is a 1-sentence description of what this does? (something something dragonfly)
Also rebase on master.
(thinking...)
@JFreegman by doing tests I see that user should now provide CFLAGS and LDFLAGs only via env(1), I'm thinking how to deal with that
Hm, I have an idea, but I'll make cosmetic changes first.
@JFreegman @iphydf How about this? I hope this will make Toxic build at Solaris/illumos too (can't test that).

Is there a technical reason users of DragonFlyBSD can't supply their custom flags in the standard way using USER_* variables? If not, I don't think a makefile overhaul is warranted for a convenience feature that only applies to users of an unorthodox system. Especially considering that it can't easily be tested on all relevant platforms for breakage. Let's just get it building and running for now.

@JFreegman in *BSD world ports systems provide environment variables CFLAGS and LDFLAGS
I, maintainer, am responsible to make sure those defaults get passed to your Makefile, so I have to do:
```
MAKE_ARGS=       USER_CFLAGS="${CFLAGS}" USER_LDFLAGS="${LDFLAGS}"
```
Also as a maintainer I'm responsible to not make a debug build.

@JFreegman but that's not over, at 0.8.2 release's state I have to make a more ugly step:
```
MAKE_ARGS+=       PREFIX="${PREFIX}"
```

@JFreegman `export PREFIX=""` setups PREFIX env(1) variable to be permanent until you exit shell (note if you're using C shell, you have to use `setenv PREFIX ""`):
```
$ export PREFIX="/raven"
$ printenv PREFIX
/raven
```
That is, you choose a PREFIX via environment variable, not via make arg.

If you take a careful look, OSX includes "osx_video.h", not <sys/videoio.h> or <linux/videodev2.h>
@JFreegman *BSD ports systems provide PREFIX as an environment variable, there's no reason to provide it as an argument to make

> @JFreegman export PREFIX="" setups PREFIX env(1) variable to be permanent until you exit shell (not if you're using C shell, you have to use setenv PREFIX "":

I understand the intent. It doesn't work though. make ignores the PREFIX environment variable, at least on my debian-based system.

> If you take a careful look, OSX includes "osx_video.h", not <sys/videoio.h> or <linux/videodev2.h>

My mistake, those should be nested or commented or both (but not in this PR).

@JFreegman weird, at my machine the same make doesn't ignore PREFIX, I appended this to the end of Toxic's Makefile:
```
show:
        @echo ${PREFIX}
```
And here's result:
```
% env PREFIX="/usr" gmake show
/usr
% env PREFIX="/raven" gmake show
/raven
```

Output based on commit ec553cd:

```
$ sudo make uninstall
[...]
$ which toxic
$
$ export PREFIX="/home/jfreegman/temp"
$ echo $PREFIX
/home/jfreegman/temp
$ sudo make install
[...]
Installing toxic executable
Installing desktop file
Installing data files
Installing man pages
$ ls /home/jfreegman/temp
$
$ which toxic
/usr/local/bin/toxic
```

@JFreegman or even better without any changes:
```
% env PREFIX="/raven" gmake help
-- Targets --
  all:       Build toxic and documentation [DEFAULT]
  toxic:     Build toxic
  doc:       Build documentation
  install:   Build toxic and install it in PREFIX (default PREFIX is "/raven")
  uninstall: Remove toxic from PREFIX (default PREFIX is "/raven")
  clean:     Remove built files
  help:      This help

-- Variables --
  DISABLE_X11:            Set to "1" to force building without X11 support
  DISABLE_AV:             Set to "1" to force building without audio call support
  DISABLE_SOUND_NOTIFY:   Set to "1" to force building without sound notification support
  DISABLE_DESKTOP_NOTIFY: Set to "1" to force building without desktop notifications support
  DISABLE_QRCODE:         Set to "1" to force building without QR export support
  DISABLE_QRPNG:          Set to "1" to force building without QR exported as PNG support
  ENABLE_PYTHON:          Set to "1" to enable building with Python scripting support
  USER_CFLAGS:            Add custom flags to default CFLAGS
  USER_LDFLAGS:           Add custom flags to default LDFLAGS
  PREFIX:                 Specify a prefix directory for binaries, data files,... (default is "/raven")
  DESTDIR:                Specify a directory where to store installed files (mainly for packaging purpose)
  MANDIR:                 Specify a directory where to store man pages (default is "/raven/share/man")

-- Environment Variables --
  CFLAGS:                 Add custom flags to default CFLAGS
  LDFLAGS:                Add custom flags to default LDFLAGS
  USER_CFLAGS:            Add custom flags to default CFLAGS
  USER_LDFLAGS:           Add custom flags to default LDFLAGS
  PREFIX:                 Specify a prefix directory for binaries, data files,... (default is "/raven")
  DESTDIR:                Specify a directory where to store installed files (mainly for packaging purpose)
  MANDIR:                 Specify a directory where to store man pages (default is "/raven/share/man")
```
I wonder what's wrong with GNU make provided by Debian?
@JFreegman oh, wait, I get it now: your sudo config ignores environment variables.
@JFreegman you have to configure sudo to keep environment variables, awesome, isn't it?

> oh, wait, I get it now: your sudo config ignores environment variables.

I don't think that's the case because setting an environment variable for CFLAGS works as intended.
@JFreegman try running `make install` without sudo, you're installing it in your home directory anyway

> @JFreegman try running make install without sudo, you're installing it in your home directory anyway

Strangely enough that did work. We're going to have to mention that caveat somewhere since this is the default setting that most people are running.

@JFreegman I use doas instead of sudo, it's more secure and easier to configure :P
```
% cat /raven/etc/doas.conf
permit keepenv :wheel
% setenv PREFIX /home/mazocomp/temp
% doas printenv PREFIX
doas (mazocomp@mazocomp.lan) password: 
/home/mazocomp/temp
```

@JFreegman I've updated INSTALL.md, now it is:
```
make
sudo env PREFIX="/where/to/install" make install
```
but `sudo make PREFIX="/where/to/install" install` is still legal

Hm, interesting, [apparently env can by used like that too](https://linux.die.net/man/1/env). I remember setting up FreeBSD builds for c-toxcore and the regular `VAR=VAL command` not working in tcsh, so I had to use `env VAR=VAL command` instead, but I thought it was some tcsh-specific built-in function, not a standard program. Still, `VAR=VAL command` is more common in bash, though I'm not sure if I should really block the PR on that since both ways are valid.
There, retracted.

```
- echo $$f | sed "s/.*\.//"
+ echo $${f##*.}
```

Even shorter, and part of POSIX shell (parameter expansion).
@avoidr wow, that's so inconvenient, Vim's syntax highlighting thinks that's a comment.

@avoidr 
```
Installing man pages
/bin/sh: f##*.: not found
/bin/sh: f##*.: not found
```

I don't know, it works in straight shell: `f=toxic.conf.5; echo ${f##*.}`

I did not test it in a Makefile, I was just saying anyway.

>Vim's syntax highlighting thinks that's a comment.

Then that's a bug.
@avoidr oh, that's a stupid font in github, I didn't notice curly braces.
Are you all waiting for me to sign the CLA?
No, but can you sign your commits and rebase on master? If you can't sign your commits, I can do that for you. Let me know.
@iphydf why sign commits and why rebase the fork?
(note that GPG tool is not available to me)
Rebasing on master avoids a merge commit. It's a bit wasteful to have 50% of the PR be merge commits. I've done it on your behalf, so nothing left to do. I'll merge once CI has run.
@iphydf PRs are wasteful, it's better to send a patch file directly, just run `patch -i path/to/patch/file` and `git commit`
